title: Thomas Cooper de Leon
text:
Thomas Cooper De Leon (May 21, 1839 – March 19, 1914) was an American journalist, author, and playwright.
Biography.
Born in <a href="Columbia%2C%20South%20Carolina">Columbia, South Carolina</a>, his parents were Mordecai Hendricks De Leon and Rebecca Lopez. His older brothers were the Confederate Surgeon-General <a href="David%20Camden%20de%20Leon">David Camden de Leon</a> and the writer and <a href="Confederate%20States%20of%20America">Confederate</a> diplomat and propagandist <a href="Edwin%20de%20Leon">Edwin de Leon</a>. Thomas Cooper de Leon served in the Confederate army from 1861 to 1865, and after the <a href="American%20Civil%20War">Civil war</a> edited "<a href="Mobile%20Register">The Mobile Register</a>", "<a href="The%20Gossip%20%28newspaper%29">The Gossip</a>", and the "<a href="Gulf%20Citizen">Gulf Citizen</a>" (both Mobile papers; 1873–96). For many years, he managed the Mobile <a href="Mardi%20Gras">Mardi Gras</a> Carnival.
He was the author of a number of works, among them being "Creole and Puritan" (1889), "The Puritan's Daughter", and "Four Years in Rebel Capitals" (1893). He also wrote a number of plays, including the comedy-drama "<a href="Pluck%20%28play%29">Pluck</a>" which was produced by <a href="Lawrence%20Barrett">Lawrence Barrett</a> in 1873. He was totally <a href="Blindness">blind</a> from 1903 and called "The Blind Laureate of the Lost Cause."
Thomas Cooper de Leon is named for the good friend of his father, the outspoken <a href="Thomas%20Cooper%20%28American%20politician%2C%20born%201759%29">Thomas Cooper</a>, president of the <a href="University%20of%20South%20Carolina">University of South Carolina</a>. He was buried in <a href="Magnolia%20Cemetery%20%28Mobile%2C%20Alabama%29">Magnolia Cemetery</a>, <a href="Mobile%2C%20Alabama">Mobile, Alabama</a>.
